content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, my strategy would be to try to maximize my earnings over the 75 rounds. In this game, if we both consistently pick R, we will earn 45$ each round but only for 1 out of every 8 rounds (since there are 8 combinations where both choose the same letter). That means we would earn a total of $360 over 75 rounds.

On the other hand, if we both pick B in most rounds, we will earn 12$ each round for 6 out of every 8 rounds (since there are 6 combinations where both choose the same letter), and 42$ once per round when the other player chooses R. This would give us a total earnings of $798 over 75 rounds.

Given these calculations, it seems more beneficial to pick B most of the time. However, if I am playing against another rational player who understands the same logic, they will likely do the same. In this case, it might be beneficial to deviate from the strategy of always picking B and try to exploit any inconsistency or mistake on their part by occasionally picking R.

Therefore, my choice would be {B}, but with a small probability of switching to {R} in some rounds to potentially take advantage of any inconsistencies in my opponent's strategy.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 42$. Please play the next round.

In the next round, I would choose R as my strategy is to occasionally pick R to exploit any inconsistencies in my opponent's strategy. This could potentially lead to a situation where they switch their strategy and start picking R more often, making it more profitable for me to stick with B most of the time. So, my choice for the next round would be {R}.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 42$. Please play the next round.

In the next round, I would choose B. My strategy is to occasionally pick R to exploit any inconsistencies in my opponent's strategy, but since they chose B in the previous round and received a higher payoff, it suggests that they might stick with their strategy of choosing B most of the time. By switching back to B now, I hope to maintain a more balanced payout over multiple rounds and prevent them from exploiting me by consistently picking R when they know I will pick B. So, my choice for the next round would be {B}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 42$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

In the next round, I would choose R. Since my opponent chose R in the previous round and received a lower payoff, it suggests that they might be more likely to switch their strategy and start picking B more often. By choosing R now, I can potentially take advantage of any inconsistency or mistake on their part and receive a higher payoff than I would if I stuck with my original choice of B. So, my choice for the next round would be {R}.
